repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Problem:
We don't have flatten / flatMap for `vim.iter` https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/26454

Solution: Implement flat, with a default depth to 1. This is similar to the way `Array.prototype.flat` works in [ECMAScript](https://tc39.es/ecma262/multipage/indexed-collections.html#sec-array.prototype.flat). It only works for list-like iterators

comment_data.body: I think this is your test file right ?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,18 @@
+local function flatten(v, max_depth, initial_depth, result)

comment_data.body: oops lol
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,18 @@
+local function flatten(v, max_depth, initial_depth, result)

comment_data.body: I couldn't find a better way to do this than making a copy. I tried for some in-place magic, but it seemed to be going nowhere. This is basically what the ES spec does as well ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -179,6 +193,45 @@ function ListIter.filter(self, f)
   return self
 end
 
+--- Flattens an |list-iterator| pipeline, un-nesting nested values
+---
+--- Example:
+---
+--- ```lua
+--- vim.iter({1, {2}, {{3}}}):flat():totable()
+--- ```
+--- (returns {1, 2, {3}})
+---
+---@param depth number|nil Depth to which iterator pipeline should be flattened
+---                        (defaults to 1)
+---@return Iter
+function Iter.flat(self, depth) -- luacheck: no unused args
+  error('flat() requires a list-like table')
+  return self
+end
+
+---@private
+function ListIter.flat(self, depth)
+  depth = depth or 1
+  local inc = self._head < self._tail and 1 or -1
+  local target = {}

comment_data.body: pairs or ipairs?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -179,6 +194,51 @@ function ListIter.filter(self, f)
   return self
 end
 
+--- Flattens an |list-iterator| pipeline, un-nesting nested values.
+--- The flattened list will exclude nil, and any values with non-numeric keys
+---
+--- Example:
+---
+--- ```lua
+--- vim.iter({1, {2}, {{3}}}):flat():totable()
+--- ```
+--- (returns `{1, 2, {3}}`)
+---
+--- ```lua
+--- vim.iter({1, {a: 2}, {{3}}}):flat():totable()
+--- ```
+--- (returns `{1, 3}`)
+---
+---@param depth number|nil Depth to which iterator pipeline should be flattened
+---                        (defaults to 1)
+---@return Iter
+function Iter.flat(self, depth) -- luacheck: no unused args
+  error('flat() requires a list-like table')
+  return self
+end
+
+---@private
+function ListIter.flat(self, depth)
+  depth = depth or 1
+  local inc = self._head < self._tail and 1 or -1
+  local target = {}
+
+  local n = 1
+  for i = self._head, self._tail - inc, inc do
+    local flattened = flatten(self._table[i], depth)
+    if flattened ~= nil then
+      for _, flat_v in pairs(flattened) do

comment_data.body: good call, should be `ipairs`. We shouldn't have any non-numeric keys at this point, but that is safer and makes it more clear what we're doing

comment_data.body: Also, the behaviors on a table like `{ nil, 2 }` or `{ [2] = 2 }` are different. It would be great if this as well can be included in the tests.

comment_data.body: hmm. not allowing `nil` in a list-like iterator seems to be a peculiarity of `Iter:new()`. The second case makes more sense, because that table isn't really list-like. I can add tests and examples in the docs for these

comment_data.body:
@clason interesting, I would have thought the structure was `{[1] = nil, [2] = 2}`, did not know lua works like this:

```lua
lua print(vim.inspect({nil, 2}))
```
gives `{ [2] = 2 }`

```suggestion
function Iter.flatten(self, depth) -- luacheck: no unused args
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -179,6 +194,59 @@ function ListIter.filter(self, f)
   return self
 end
 
+--- Flattens an |list-iterator| pipeline, un-nesting nested values.
+--- The flattened list will exclude nil, and any values with non-numeric keys
+---
+--- Example:
+---
+--- ```lua
+--- vim.iter({1, {2}, {{3}}}):flat():totable()
+--- ```
+--- (returns `{1, 2, {3}}`)
+---
+--- ```lua
+--- vim.iter({1, {a = 2}, {nil, {nil}}, {{3}}}):flat():totable()
+--- ```
+--- (returns `{1, {}, 3}`)
+---
+--- ```lua
+--- vim.iter({[2] = 2}):flat():totable()
+--- vim.iter({nil, 2})
+---
+--- ```
+--- Both give an error because the iterator being flattened is not list-like
+--- (the indices in the source table are not consecutive)
+---
+---@param depth number|nil Depth to which iterator pipeline should be flattened
+---                        (defaults to 1)
+---@return Iter
+function Iter.flat(self, depth) -- luacheck: no unused args

comment_data.body: I don't think we need to explain what "list-like" means here. There are already other places that do that, and if needs to be repeated there are more appropriate locations. For the this function's docstring, assume that "only works for list-like tables" is well understood. No need to provide anti-examples.

comment_data.body:
Only list-like tables are accepted:

```suggestion
---@param src table List-like table to flatten
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1052,6 +1120,23 @@ function M.map(f, src, ...)
   return Iter.new(src, ...):map(f):totable()
 end
 
+--- Flattens a |list-iterator|, un-nesting nested values
+---
+--- ```lua
+--- -- Equivalent to:
+--- vim.iter(src):flat():totable()
+--- ```
+---
+---@see |Iter:flat()|
+---
+---@param src table|function Table or iterator function to flatten

@@ -1052,6 +1120,23 @@ function M.map(f, src, ...)
   return Iter.new(src, ...):map(f):totable()
 end
 
+--- Flattens a |list-iterator|, un-nesting nested values
+---
+--- ```lua
+--- -- Equivalent to:
+--- vim.iter(src):flat():totable()
+--- ```
+---
+---@see |Iter:flat()|
+---
+---@param src table|function Table or iterator function to flatten
+---@param depth number|nil Depth to which the iterable should be flattened
+---                        (defaults to 1)
+---@return table
+function M.flat(src, depth, ...)
+  return Iter.new(src, ...):flat(depth):totable()

comment_data.body: Here and throughout: let's leave these kinds of formatting changes out of this PR, as it makes it more difficult to actually review what has changed. Test files are intentionally _not_ autoformatted right now, but that will (probably) change in the future, at which point these kinds of changes will be done.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -10,7 +10,7 @@ describe('vim.iter', function()
     rb:push("b")
 
     local it = vim.iter(rb)
-    eq({"a", "b"}, it:totable())
+    eq({ "a", "b" }, it:totable())

comment_data.body: since the other members here are in the imperative voice, that probably makes more sense üëç

+---

+--- ```
+---
+---@see |Iter:flat()|
+---
+---@param src table|function Table or iterator function to flatten
+---@param depth number|nil Depth to which the iterable should be flattened
+---                        (defaults to 1)
+---@return table
+function M.flat(src, depth, ...)
+  return Iter.new(src, ...):flat(depth):totable()

namely the `|list-iterator|` part

comment_data.body: Please add a proper docstring to this function (including type annotations for parameters)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -112,6 +112,21 @@ local function sanitize(t)
   return t
 end
 
+-- this returns a table that contains the flattened v

comment_data.body: Why does it not fully flatten the table? Because the default `depth` is 1? What would be the rationale of choosing 1 as the default depth? Shouldn't we flatten the entire table by default?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -179,6 +199,51 @@ function ListIter.filter(self, f)
   return self
 end
 
+--- Flattens a |list-iterator| pipeline, un-nesting nested values.
+--- The flattened list will exclude nil, and any values with non-numeric keys
+---
+--- Example:
+---
+--- ```lua
+--- vim.iter({1, {2}, {{3}}}):flatten():totable()
+--- ```
+--- (returns `{1, 2, {3}}`)
+---
+--- ```lua
+--- vim.iter({1, {a = 2}, {nil, {nil}}, {3}}):flatten():totable()
+--- ```
+--- (returns `{1, {}, 3}`)

comment_data.body:
By choosing that default, I was trying to mimic the behavior of the [ECMAScript method](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/flat) `Arrays.prototype.flat`, which was mentioned in the original issue thread. That is probably the implementation with which people are most familiar. 

Fully flattening by default is definitely another option here. ES uses a depth of infinity to fully flatten a table, but comparisons with infinity, which could be less intuitive to users. in Lua: 

```lua
-- flatten a table to infinite depth (math.huge = inf)
print(vim.inspect(vim.iter.flatten({1, {2}, {{3}}, {{{{4}}}}}, math.huge)))

```

@@ -179,6 +199,51 @@ function ListIter.filter(self, f)

 end
 
+--- Flattens a |list-iterator| pipeline, un-nesting nested values.

+--- ```
+--- (returns `{1, 2, {3}}`)
+---
+--- ```lua
+--- vim.iter({1, {a = 2}, {nil, {nil}}, {3}}):flatten():totable()
+--- ```
+--- (returns `{1, {}, 3}`)

comment_data.body: I see, that makes a sense and I'm now convinced with `depth` defaulting to 1. New (better) defaults for the new API is good :)

comment_data.body:
`flat` is shorter and is what https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/26454 specifies.
```suggestion
Iter:flat({depth})                                         *Iter:flat()*
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3388,6 +3405,29 @@ Iter:find({f})                                                   *Iter:find()*
     Return: ~
         any
 
+Iter:flatten({depth})                                         *Iter:flatten()*

comment_data.body: See https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/26786#discussion_r1438688152
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3388,6 +3405,29 @@ Iter:find({f})                                                   *Iter:find()*
     Return: ~
         any
 
+Iter:flatten({depth})                                         *Iter:flatten()*

comment_data.body: This is not worth adding as a `vim.iter` function. We can always change that later, but for now we should not enter this one-way door. `vim.iter(...):flat():totable()` is perfectly reasonable.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3296,6 +3296,23 @@ filter({f}, {src}, {...})                                  *vim.iter.filter()*
     See also: ~
       ‚Ä¢ |Iter:filter()|
 
+flatten({src}, {depth}, {...})                            *vim.iter.flatten()*

comment_data.body: Shorter is better. @gpanders do you mind if we use `flat`

comment_data.body:
> Shorter is better. @gpanders do you mind if we use `flat`

Consistent is also better. `flat()` feels like a very bizarre function name, it is neither a noun nor a verb. The rest of the API in vim.iter() (and our API in general) uses verbs for function names to indicate it ‚Äúdoes something‚Äù.

`flatten` is also, as far as I know, much more common in other languages. In fact, aside from the one JavaScript implementation you linked to I‚Äôve never seen such a function called `flat` https://rosettacode.org/wiki/Flatten_a_list

https://v2.ocaml.org/api/List.html#VALflatten

https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/iter/trait.Iterator.html#method.flatten
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3388,6 +3405,29 @@ Iter:find({f})                                                   *Iter:find()*
     Return: ~
         any
 
+Iter:flatten({depth})                                         *Iter:flatten()*

comment_regular_data.body: news.txt already includes an entry on `vim.iter`, so I don't think I am going to update that for this

I would suggest we add *comprehensive* tests on various corner cases about the behavior (and document them well), even when a NOT-list-like table is given, or a table contains `nil`, etc.:

```lua
> vim.tbl_flatten({1, {2, 3, nil, 4}, 5, {6, a = 7, b = 8}})
< { 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6 }

> vim.iter.flat({1, {2, 3, nil, 4}, 5, {6, a = 7, b = 8}})
< { 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 8, 7 }
```

> I would suggest we add _comprehensive_ tests on various corner cases about the behavior (and document them well), even when a NOT-list-like table is given, or a table contains `nil`, etc.:
> 
> ```lua
> > vim.tbl_flatten({1, {2, 3, nil, 4}, 5, {6, a = 7, b = 8}})
> < { 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6 }
> 
> > vim.iter.flat({1, {2, 3, nil, 4}, 5, {6, a = 7, b = 8}})
> < { 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 8, 7 }
> ```



that's a great call ! I tested when the first level was not a list-like table, but not the inner-levels ü§í . This is also potentially a bug with `Iter:new()` since it doesn't check deeper than one level in validating when validating that an iterator is list-like https://github.com/rudiejd/neovim/blob/3de60f4c9c68a9571d292e0e495a7a30ee071849/runtime/lua/vim/iter.lua#L1007-L1017

is the desired behavior here to ignore key-like values and nil a-la `vim.tbl_flatten`, or to include them in the same order? I'm just going to go with ignoring them for now for consistency and document this as such, but it's an interesting question.

repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

title: feat(vim.iter): flattening for list-like iterators
